items.title: 'Retribution' concerns amid surge in Islamophobic attacks after Bondi shooting
items.description: A rise in Islamophobic incidents prompts warnings from Muslim organisations that their communities are at risk of "retribution" and "collective punishment" following the mass shooting.

items.title: Clean-up begins after WA's north endures 'absolutely terrifying' cyclone
items.description: Emergency services travel to the Dampier Peninsula to assess the damage caused by the category three system, which crossed the coast on Tuesday afternoon.

items.title: 'Disgraceful' acts of looting in bushfire-ravaged community
items.description: After 19 homes were destroyed by bushfire in a picturesque east coast Tasmanian community, residents are now reporting instances of looting — described by the state premier as "disgraceful".

items.title: Crown casino workers announce New Year's Eve strike amid wage row
items.description: About 500 workers at Melbourne's Crown casino will stop work tonight after rejecting a proposal they say will cut pay for new workers and imperil those currently employed.

items.title: 'White Australia' flyer letterbox drop in Newcastle sparks police investigation
items.description: NSW Premier Chris Minns said police would "throw the book" at anyone behind flyers distributed to inner-city Newcastle letterboxes.

items.title: Calls for critics to 'grow up' after outcry over period mention on BBC
items.description: Alex Hartley says she was stunned by the reaction to her talking about her period during the BBC's radio commentary of the third Ashes Test.

items.title: Revellers gather at sites across Australia for NYE celebrations
items.description: Revellers are jostling to secure a prime spot to enjoy celebrations taking place across Australia to mark the start of 2026.

items.title: Ex-Australian cricketer Damien Martyn seriously ill in induced coma
items.description: Former Australian Test and limited overs batsman Damien Martyn is in hospital in Queensland in an induced coma after falling ill this week.

items.title: Rule breach in final stretch of Sydney to Hobart sees rival crowned winner
items.description: Double-handed Min River makes history by becoming the first double-handed yacht to take out the overall win in the Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race and the first to do so with a female skipper.

items.title: Praise for 'brave' officer's rescue bid as flooding claims a life
items.description: Police have renewed warnings about driving in floodwaters after a tragedy in Queensland's Gulf Country as the region endures a fourth day of drenching rain.

items.title: Harvard physicist says interstellar object may be alien tech

featured_image.name: Hubble observes unusual twin jets from interstellar object 3I/ATLAS as it leaves the solar system

items.description:
Harvard physicist Avi Loeb has intensified his claim that the interstellar visitor 3I/ATLAS may be an alien spacecraft, citing new Hubble Space Telescope images that reveal an unusual dual-jet structure as the object speeds away from Earth.

Observations captured on December 12 and 27 show two distinct jets of material streaming from the object's nucleus, with one pointing toward the Sun and a weaker jet extending in the opposite direction[1][2][3]. As one jet brightens, the other fades in what Loeb describes as a "clean, repeatable and geometrically consistent swap"[4].

Loeb, a Harvard astrophysicist who leads the Galileo Project, has ranked 3I/ATLAS a "four" on his personal scale of zero to ten, where zero represents a natural comet and ten signifies an active alien threat[5][6]. "You can't just say, 'I know the answer' and ignore the anomalies. That's not viable," Loeb said[5][6].

3I/ATLAS, discovered on July 1, 2025, is only the third confirmed interstellar object to visit our solar system, following 'Oumuamua in 2017 and 2I/Borisov in 2019[7][8]. The object passed Earth on December 19 at a safe distance of roughly 170 million miles and is now heading toward Jupiter, where it will make its closest approach on March 16, 2026[5][9].

items.title: Iran suspends work in 21 provinces as protests spread

featured_image.name: Surge of Economic Pain Pushes Iranians to the Streets

items.description: Demonstrations across Iran escalated on Tuesday as university students joined shopkeepers and bazaar merchants in protests sparked by the Iranian rial plunging to a record low of 1.42 million per dollar and inflation surging to 42.2%[1][2][3][4][5]. The unrest, now in its third consecutive day, prompted the government to suspend official work in 21 of the country's 31 provinces[2] and offer a 20-point economic plan[6] in a notable departure from the regime's typically harsh response to dissent.

items.title: Copper surges 41% in 2025 on AI demand, mine disasters

featured_image.name: Copper on pace for best year since 2009 as AI demand, supply fears fuel record price rally

items.description:
Copper has surged to record highs in 2025, posting its strongest annual gain since the financial crisis as artificial intelligence infrastructure drives unprecedented demand while a wave of mine disasters tightens global supply. The industrial metal climbed approximately 41% this year, reaching a record $12,960 per metric ton on the London Metal Exchange on Monday before pulling back slightly[1][2][3][4].

The rally marks the metal's best performance since 2009, when it gained over 140% as economies recovered from the global financial crisis[1][2][3]. As of Tuesday, copper notched its eighth consecutive day of gains, its longest winning streak in eight years[2].

items.title: UAE to withdraw troops from Yemen after Saudi ultimatum

featured_image.name: Saudis Say Airstrike in Yemen Targeted Arms From U.A.E.

items.description:
The United Arab Emirates announced Tuesday it will withdraw its remaining military forces from Yemen, hours after Saudi Arabia bombed a Yemeni port and issued an ultimatum demanding Emirati troops leave within 24 hours, marking the most serious confrontation between the two Gulf allies in decades[1][2][3].

The escalation unfolded after Saudi-led coalition forces struck Mukalla port early Tuesday morning, targeting what Riyadh described as weapons shipments from the UAE intended for southern separatists. Yemen's Presidential Leadership Council head, Rashad al-Alimi, subsequently cancelled a joint defense agreement with Abu Dhabi and declared a 90-day state of emergency[4][5][6].

items.title: CIA conducted first drone strike inside Venezuela

featured_image.name: 'This Is an Act of War': CIA Carried Out Drone Strike on Port ...

items.description:
The CIA carried out a drone strike on a port facility inside Venezuela earlier this month, marking the first confirmed US attack on Venezuelan soil since the Trump administration launched an aggressive military campaign in the Caribbean four months ago[1][2][3].

President Donald Trump publicly acknowledged the strike on December 29, stating there was a "major explosion" in a dock area where boats were allegedly loaded with drugs[1][4][3]. The operation, which CNN first reported, targeted a remote dock on Venezuela's coast that US officials believed was used by the Tren de Aragua gang to store and transport narcotics[1][2][5]. No casualties were reported as the facility was empty at the time of the strike[1][2][6].

Trump initially revealed the attack during a radio interview on December 26, saying the US had destroyed a "big facility where the ships come from" two nights earlier, placing the strike around December 24[7][8]. When pressed by reporters about whether the CIA or military conducted the operation, Trump declined to provide details. "I know exactly who it was, but I don't want to say who it was," he said at his Mar-a-Lago residence[4][9].

items.title: Global markets close 2025 with sharp volatility

featured_image.name: ‘You Had to Be Brave': Wall Street Remembers a Wild 2025

items.description:
Global stock markets closed out 2025 with a year defined by extraordinary volatility and divergent regional performances, as investors navigated policy whiplash from Washington and dramatic swings in commodities and cryptocurrencies.

U.S. markets finished the year near record highs despite violent mid-year turbulence. The S&P 500 gained approximately 17.4% for 2025, while the Nasdaq Composite surged 21%[1][2][3]. However, these gains masked what traders called one of the most volatile years in recent memory, punctuated by President Donald Trump's tariff announcements in April that sent global markets into a tailspin[4][5].

The defining moment came April 2-3, when Trump's "Liberation Day" tariff announcement triggered the worst two-day decline for the S&P 500 since the pandemic began, with the index teetering on the brink of a bear market[4][5]. Markets rebounded dramatically on April 9 when Trump paused many tariffs for 90 days, with the S&P 500 soaring 9.5% in a single session—its largest one-day gain since October 2008[4].

items.title: China condemns record US arms sale as Taiwan drills escalate

featured_image.name: What to know about China's drills around Taiwan as rockets fired on ...

items.description:
China's foreign minister condemned a record US arms sale to Taiwan on Tuesday as Beijing conducted a second day of military exercises encircling the island, firing rockets closer to Taiwan's main landmass than in previous drills.

Foreign Minister Wang Yi said China must "firmly oppose and forcefully counter" the large-scale US arms sales to Taiwan during an annual diplomatic symposium in Beijing[1][2]. His comments marked the most senior Chinese official response to the $11 billion weapons package announced by the US State Department earlier this month[3][4].

items.title: Iran president orders talks with protesters over economic crisis

featured_image.name: Iran's government offers dialogue to protesters

items.description:
Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian called on his government to address the "legitimate demands" of protesters Tuesday, following two days of demonstrations in Tehran sparked by the national currency's collapse to a historic low and soaring inflation that has pushed the country toward an economic crisis[1][2][3][4].

The rial plunged to 1.42 million against the U.S. dollar on Sunday before recovering slightly to 1.38 million on Monday, according to multiple reports[5][6][7]. The currency has lost more than two-thirds of its value since 2022, when it traded at approximately 430,000 to the dollar[5]. Annual inflation reached 42.2 percent in December, with food prices surging 72 percent year-over-year, according to Iran's Statistical Center[5][8][9].

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].

items.title: Saudi Arabia warns UAE-backed forces are a threat to its national security

featured_image.name: Saudi coalition will counter Yemen separatists undermining de-escalation

items.description:
Saudi Arabia declared a United Arab Emirates-backed separatist advance in Yemen a threat to its national security on Tuesday, marking the strongest public rebuke yet between the Gulf powers as their decade-long alliance in Yemen's civil war fractures over competing strategic interests[1][2].

The warning came hours after a Saudi-led coalition airstrike struck weapons shipments at Yemen's Mukalla port that Riyadh said originated from the UAE, intensifying a confrontation that threatens to reshape the region's power dynamics. Yemen's Saudi-backed Presidential Leadership Council cancelled its defense pact with the UAE and demanded all Emirati forces leave the country within 24 hours[1][3].

"The Kingdom expresses its disappointment by the actions taken by the brotherly United Arab Emirates, pressuring the Southern Transitional Council's forces to conduct military operations on the southern border of the Kingdom," Saudi Arabia's foreign ministry said in a statement[1][2]. The ministry called the UAE's actions "highly dangerous" and warned that any threat to Saudi national security is "a red line"[1][2].

items.title: South Korea's Lee to visit China next week

featured_image.name: Issues at stake in summit between China's Xi and South Korea's Lee

items.description:
South Korean President Lee Jae Myung will travel to China from January 4 to 7 for his first state visit to Beijing since taking office in June, the Blue House announced Tuesday[1][2][3][4]. The trip marks the first visit by a South Korean leader to China in six years and comes as Lee seeks to restore ties strained under his predecessor[1][5].

Lee will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing from January 4 to 6 for a summit and state dinner before traveling to Shanghai, according to presidential spokesperson Kang Yu-jung[3][6]. The visit reciprocates Xi's three-day state visit to South Korea in late October, which was the Chinese leader's first trip to the country in 11 years[1][5][7].
